question: In the context of the Riemann integral, if we have a function \( f(x) \) that is defined over the interval \( (a, b) \) and has a finite number of discontinuities, how does the presence of \( k \) discontinuities affect the value of the integral \( \int_a^b f(x) \, dx \)? If \( k = 3 \), what can we conclude about the integral?
solution:
The Riemann integral states that the value of the integral \( \int_a^b f(x) \, dx \) is not affected by a finite number of discontinuities, provided that the function is reasonable (i.e., bounded and defined almost everywhere). Therefore, even if there are \( k = 3 \) discontinuities in the function \( f(x) \), the integral remains the same as if those points were not present.

Thus, we can conclude that:

\[
\int_a^b f(x) \, dx \text{ is unaffected by } k = 3 \text{ discontinuities.}
\]

The answer is:
\[
\text{The integral remains the same.}
\]
